title: Collingwood apologises after requesting will donations | ABC NEWS
description: Collingwood has apologised after sending letters to older fans asking them to consider leaving donations to the AFL club in their wills. More than 8,000 members aged 50 or older received the letters. title: Australian exporters could be refunded if Trump tariffs are ruled unlawful | ABC NEWS
description: The US Supreme Court will soon decide on whether Donald Trump has the authority to impose trade tariffs worldwide. Modelling shows Australian exporters may be owed more than $1.4 billion in refunds should the court rule against the US president. Luke Branson from EY Australia says refunds will not be automatic and exporters must apply for them. title: Bikie found guilty of murder by paying sniper to assassinate ex-Rebels boss | ABC NEWS
description: A bikie who paid a trained sniper to assassinate former Rebels boss Nick Martin has been found guilty of his murder. 43-year-old David Pye was convicted in WA's Supreme Court of six charges, including the murder of Martin who was his former friend, and trying to arrange the murders of another rival bikie and his ex-girlfriend. title: US-led ‘Board of Peace’ plans Gaza rebuild, possible Iran war | ABC NEWS
description: The Board of Peace, made up of countries invited by the US, has met for the first time to discuss Gaza's future. No Palestinian representatives attended. Australia, the UK, France and Canada have not paid the $US1 billion fee for permanent membership. Donald Trump has promised $US10 billion in US aid for Gaza. The meeting also discussed the chance of war with Iran. title: Can Indonesia afford to join Trump's Board of Peace for $1 billion USD? | Asia News Week | ABC NEWS
description: 0:00 Can Indonesia afford to join Donald Trump's Board of Peace? 1:21 What does Indonesia's former ambassador to the US Dino Patti Djalal make of the first Board of Peace meeting? 2:40 What problems could arise from Indonesia participating in the Board of Peace? 4:04 Could Indonesia withdraw from the Board of Peace?  Prabowo Subianto's participation in Donald Trump's Board of Peace has been heavily criticised back home in Indonesia. The country has always advocated for an independent Palestine, and there are concerns the board will promote US and Israeli interests. Many are also wondering how Indonesia will afford the $1 billion USD membership fee. Dr Dino Patti Djalal, former Indonesian ambassador to the United States and the former Vice Foreign Minister of Indonesia tells Asia News Week's Yvonne Yong why he thinks the Board of Peace "has many flaws". title: Big one day sell-offs blamed on algorithms and short-term trading, says Morningstar
description: During reporting season, numerous stocks like AMP, Temple and Webster, Zip and Pro Medicus have their seen stock prices plunge by around 30 per cent in one day as investors react to the corporate reports in the current half-year earnings season. In many cases though, Morningstar's equity market strategist Lochlan Halloway says, the result alone doesn't justify the steep price fall, and the fall may instead be due to changing market dynamics and the way equities are traded. Mr Halloway points to short term capital flooding the market and algorithmic trades. He says, "the fastest reaction is not the most considered on, nor is it necessarily right." He says broadly company reports have been positive and earnings are picking up, with the resources sector doing well. Alicia Barry presents this segment and looks at earnings season so far as well as how a strong jobs market may heap pressure on the RBA to raise interest rates again in 2026.  #ABCBusiness  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Trump's latest Iran comments lead to oil price surge, ASX retreats | Finance Report | ABC NEWS
description: Donald Trump's latest remarks about Iran — on whether or not the US will attack the Islamic nation in the next 10 days — led to oil prices surging to a six-month high and falls across global markets.  Meanwhile, shares of Rio Tinto, Inghams and Guzman Y Gomez plunged after they announced profit results which underwhelmed investors on the Australian share market, as finance presenter David Chau explains. title: WA could stop cats roaming under proposed legislation | ABC NEWS
description: Western Australia's Local Government Minister Hannah Beazley has announced plans to change the law to let councils require cats to stay on their owners' properties. Currently, councils need approval from a state parliamentary committee to make rules about cats. More than 20 councils have been refused permission. Bruce Webber from the WA Feral Cat Working Group says if the bill passes, councils will be able to make rules to keep cats on their owners' properties and limit how many cats people can own. title: First Northern Territory women's prison will house up to 95 offenders | ABC NEWS
description: Thirty-five female prisoners have moved into the Northern Territory's first women's jail, near Alice Springs, with more expected in the coming months. The NT government has been renovating the former youth justice facility at the Alice Springs Correctional Centre into the women's prison over the past 12 months, at a cost of $10.35 million. Northern Territory Corrections Commissioner Matthew Varley said the first stage of upgrades allowed space for 35 prisoners, but up to 95 women would be accommodated when renovations were completed at the end of April. Victoria Ellis has this story for ABC News Northern Territory. title: Police say 'hope is fading' in hunt for kidnapped Sydney grandfather | ABC NEWS
description: Police have located what they say is the "stronghold" of the kidnappers of Chris Baghsarian.  Detectives have established a crime scene at a property in Sydney's north-west as the search for the missing grandfather enters its seventh day.  Police are appealing for anyone in the Dural area who witnessed anything suspicious to contact Crime Stoppers.
